Australian Human Rights Commission AI - Submission

At Braneshop we‚Äôre keen to see AI develop positively in our community. The rules and regulation around AI will play a key role in ensuring that the AI that is ultimately built and used ends up creating good community outcomes.

The Australian Human Rights Commission recently put out a call for consultation on AI - Governance and Leadership. The deadline for a submission is the 18th of March at 5pm (so there‚Äôs still time if you‚Äôre quick!)

Working with Martin and Sam at Northraine and other interested parties, we prepared a joint submission, which you can read here: Our HRC Submission.

One really important message regarding ethics and AI, that I‚Äôve seen recently, comes from the following papers: The Ethics of AI Ethics ‚Äì An Evaluation of Guidelines.

Quoting the author:

‚ÄúEthics is then no longer understood as a deontologically inspired tick-box exercise, but as a project of advancing personalities, changing attitudes, strengthen responsibilities and gaining courage to refrain from certain actions, which are deemed unethical. [‚Ä¶] It should not be the objective of ethics to stifle activity, but to do the exact opposite, i.e.¬†broadening the scope of action, uncovering blind spots, promoting autonomy and freedom, and fostering self-responsibility.‚Äù - Thilo Hagendorff

Emphasis mine.

This is a crucial and important thought when considereding any kind of ‚Äúnormative‚Äù, rule-based, punishment-driven acitivies, over those that enrich, embolden and allow for, and encourage, the growth of people and communities.
